awd_titl_txt: Emerging Materials for Energy storage and environmental Research enabled through Atomic Layer Deposition, (EMERALD)
awd_abstract_narration:
There is a compelling need for an inexpensive, off-the-grid, technology in which solar energy is captured and used to produce a fuel - hydrogen - for heating and electricity when the sun does not shine and a disinfectant - hypochlorite (chemical formula NaOCl) - to create potable water.  The worldwide need for potable water is great. A sixth of the world's population have no access to improved water supplies and far more consume contaminated water every day. This US-Republic of Ireland-Northern Ireland, United Kingdom research collaboration project involves harvesting the energy of sunlight to split saltwater into its chemical components: hydrogen, hypochlorite and another valuable product, caustic (NaOH).  This technology is amenable to a modular system approach which would provide distributed power and potable water in areas with less infrastructure or during natural disasters. The project provides an international and multidisciplinary research experience for the involved students. The project also leverages Stanford's RISE outreach program to inspire students to consider further education and careers in the STEM fields using hands-on research experiences relevant to photovoltaics, motivated by the goal of advancing infrastructure in the developing world.

This project is a multidisciplinary research project involving Stanford, Tyndall National Institute/University College Cork, Republic of Ireland and Queens University, Belfast, Northern Ireland United Kingdom. The collaboration involves multidisciplinary research on novel catalysts, corrosion protections layers for efficient earth-abundant light absorbers, and electrochemical cell design. Tasks will be performed on 1) new, inexpensive materials that enable efficient saltwater splitting, 2) methods for protecting silicon solar cell materials when they are exposed to saltwater, and 3) optimized designs for saltwater splitting devices.  The project will investigate electrode materials selection and composition optimization, atomic layer deposition (ALD) methods to control local catalytic and electronic properties over highly porous electrodes, and the impact these factors have on cell efficiency and durability while minimizing platinum group metal use.  The research will be related to two different devices, one an integrated and highly-efficient silicon photoelectrochemical cell, and the other an electrochemical cell which can be powered by an external photovoltaic array. A multiphysics modelling effort will inform the design details in order to optimize the cells for efficiency. Collectively, the team of researchers in the US, Ireland and Northern Ireland will assemble and test devices to demonstrate the performance and stability of the materials and device designs developed in this project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

There is a compelling need for an inexpensive, off-the-grid, solar energy-driven technology capable of producing a fuel – hydrogen - for heating and electricity when the sun does not shine and a disinfectant – hypochlorite – to create potable water.   The need for potable water worldwide is great. A sixth of the world population have no access to improved water supplies and far more consume contaminated water every day. This US-Ireland research collaboration project involved multidisciplinary research on novel catalysts, corrosion protection layers for efficient earth-abundant light absorbers, and electrochemical cell design.  The research included investigations of electrode materials selection and composition optimization, atomic layer deposition (ALD) methods to control local catalytic and electronic properties metal oxide catalyst coatings, and the impact these factors have on cell efficiency and durability while minimizing platinum group metal use.  This project focused on two different devices, one an integrated and highly-efficient silicon photoelectrochemical cell, and the other an electrochemical cell that can be powered by an external array of solar cells. In collaboration with US-Ireland partner researchers at University College Cork (Ireland) and Queens University Belfast (Northern Ireland), the research effort explored the properties and electrochemical behavior of nanometer thickness coatings containing iridium oxide, perhaps the most effective catalyst for water oxidation because of its activity and stability over a wide range of electrochemical conditions.  Important topics investigated included the mechanisms responsible for iridium loss during oxygen evolution electrocatalysis, and how combining iridium oxide with titanium dioxide – a normally inactive material for water oxidation - both in ultrathin alloy coatings and in multilayer structures could improve performance over that measured for iridium oxide alone.  This project also extended the exploration of nanostructured iridium oxide alloys and multilayer catalyst coatings to chloride evolution electrochemistry, using saltwater to form both hydrogen and hypochlorite reaction products.  The results obtained will be important in developing design rules for electrode materials and catalysts in future, field-deployable, water and chloride oxidation cells for fuel and disinfectant production using electricity from renewable sources.  

Broader Impacts:

The students and postdoctoral researchers involved in this project gained knowledge and access to a wide range of synthesis, fabrication and characterization tools important for making and evaluating (photo)electrochemical devices and materials. They have had numerous opportunities during this project for professional development including attendance of and presentations at local and national scientific conferences.  The project supported research by Ph.D. students Chor Seng Tan, Wanliang Tan and Robert Tang-Kong, all of whom graduated with their doctorates at the end of August 2019. In addition, the project has engaged the efforts of postdocs Dr. Aein Babadi and Dr. Marco Villena. Dr. Villena completed his postdoc term in late 2018. Dr. Babadi investigated structure rel-property relations in ALD-grown oxygen evolution and chlorine evolution catalyst layers and the ALD surface functionalization of catalysts, such as ultra-thin titanium oxide coatings that enhance the performance of iridium oxide. She completed her postdoc appointment in late 2021. The development of a compact, and high efficiency integrated silicon photoelectrochemical cells in this project opens up possible applications for off-the-grid synthesis of hydrogen fuel and hypochlorite as a water disinfectant and surface cleaner. This could have important applications in the developing world and in remote communities and work sites where supplies of fuel and clean water may be absent or insecure.

 


Last Modified: 05/31/2022
Modified by: Paul C Mcintyre
